content.definition: A clinical syndrome resulting from distal embolization of atheromatous debris (cholesterol crystals, platelet aggregates, fibrin) from a proximal arterial source to the digital vessels of the foot. Characterized by acute onset of painful, cyanotic digits with preserved proximal pulses, often occurring after arterial instrumentation.

progression: May progress to gangrene of digits

diagnosis.biopsy: Skin or muscle biopsy showing cholesterol clefts (pathognomonic but rarely needed)

amputation: Limited digital amputation for demarcated gangrene

prognosis: May require minor amputation of digits

learning_objectives: Recognize classic presentation of atheroembolic syndrome
Understand the paradox of preserved pulses with ischemic digits
Know sources and triggers of atheroembolism
clinical_pearls: Preserved pulses + cyanotic toes = think atheroembolism
Anticoagulation may WORSEN atheroembolism (removes protective thrombus)
Look for source: aortic/iliac atheroma or popliteal aneurysm
Hollenhorst plaques on fundoscopy = cholesterol emboli
Let gangrenous tissue demarcate before amputation
